metaphor.core: The non-linear, interwoven narratives of Pulp Fiction, managed by a 'director' who prioritizes and switches between stories, serve as a metaphor for React's concurrent rendering capabilities, particularly `useTransition`, where React can work on multiple UI updates simultaneously in the background, pausing low-priority work to handle urgent user interactions.

mapping.reactConcept: Different UI updates or rendering tasks
React's scheduler prioritizing and managing rendering
A synchronous, heavy rendering task blocking the main thread

mapping.fictionElement: Urgent phone call interrupting the scene
mapping.reactConcept: Urgent user input (e.g., typing, clicks) during heavy rendering

mapping.fictionElement: Quentin's custom switchboard (The Scheduler) to pause/resume reels
mapping.reactConcept: useTransition pausing low-priority rendering to allow high-priority updates
Responsive UI where user input is handled immediately, and background work resumes smoothly
Blocking renders cause UI freezes, concurrent renders create fluid, responsive experiences

metaphor.narrativeArc: The module progresses from explaining the concept of a 'tapestry' of UI states (concurrent mode) to the problems of 'linear cuts' (blocking renders), then introduces the 'Scheduler' (useTransition) as a solution, compares the outcomes of 'traffic jams vs. dance' (blocking vs. concurrent), and finally summarizes the benefits in a 'premiere' real-world example.

problems: Poor user experience when interacting with slow UIs

chapters.title: The Linear Cut
chapters.focus: Demonstrates the problem of blocking renders in legacy React.

chapters.title: The Scheduler
chapters.focus: Explains and demonstrates useTransition for managing concurrent updates.

chapters.title: Traffic Jam vs. Dance
chapters.focus: Compares blocking vs. concurrent rendering side-by-side.

chapters.title: The Premiere
chapters.focus: Summarizes the benefits with a real-world example (responsive search).
